item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
arraybolt3:

cd /sys/class/leds/smc::kbd_backlight && grep . *

item.title: Virtualbox error Kernel driver not installed (rc=-1908)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: VirtualBox just not working with Secure Boot enabled is a big problem, so I’ll put this on my todo list and hopefully find a solution soon.

item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
Avoca:

However, TAILS OS seems to have solved it as, once loaded, the standard keyboard backlight adjustments work. Never needed to try/look into the actual ‘settings’ system, so I don’t know.

Tails doesn’t have user-sysmaint-split or a similar “isolate root access into a non-standard user account”, so it doesn’t have the same issues there. GNOME also has built-in support for adjusting the backlight.

Avoca:

Happy to offer my help/computer for testing a fix if it helps. Proton Mail, Tuta Mail, PGP, Session, Delta Chat, etc, available if it helps.

What would probably be most helpful is if you could share the output of cd /sys/class/leds/smc::kbd_backlight && grep . *. This will show the names and contents of all the files in that directory. That might provide enough information to write a utility that will work with Kicksecure and will allow adjusting the backlight, and depending on how things go, that might be something that can be integrated into Kicksecure later (though @Patrick would be the one to decide that).

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
Correct!

Initially I cloned from 32GB USB to 64GB USB drive’s and it worked, no issues.

I then tried from the 64GB USB to a 32GB MicroSD and it failed with ~“insufficient memory” as the error message.

So, off the the store for me.

Still very hopeful though.

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: Is the SD card bigger than the USB drive? If so, it should just work. (Growing the root partition could be challenging, I’m not sure we have that documented anywhere, but even without growing the partition, the system should work.) Of course, if the card is smaller, then there are problems. Generally it’s a good idea to clone from a smaller drive to a bigger drive rather than cloning between two drives of the same size, since two drives that claim to be the same size (32 GB for instance) might be slightly different sizes “under the hood”, which can give you the same complications as cloning to a too-small drive.

item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
Thanks, I figured Apple would be behind yet another UEFI/BIOS hurdle.

However, TAILS OS seems to have solved it as, once loaded, the standard keyboard backlight adjustments work. Never needed to try/look into the actual ‘settings’ system, so I don’t know.

Happy to offer my help/computer for testing a fix if it helps. Proton Mail, Tuta Mail, PGP, Session, Delta Chat, etc, available if it helps.

Cheers.

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
Thanks.

So far so good. I am using Linux dd to ‘clone’ the USB to a MicroSD card and, apart from a device size mismatch(my bad), its looking good.

I can boot my MicroSD TAILS OS from the grub boot menu whilst its in the SD slot or when mounted in a USB-A/C adaptor, but they are different from the Kicksecure boot method, so it remains to be seen if it works.

But, I’ll report back when I have purchased a matching size MicroSD.

I’m very hopeful.

item.title: Virtualbox error Kernel driver not installed (rc=-1908)
item.dc:creator: @ValdemarJo
item.description: It looks like the problem is the latest update, I reinstalled the system again and did everything new, but nothing helped. I would be grateful if someone tries to run any operating system in VirtualBox in the latest version of KickSecure with secureboot enabled.

item.title: Can't open proton VPN in kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: We don’t usually change the polkit policies unless necessary for security reasons. One exception is Flatpak; we changed its polkit policies to prohibit things like unprivileged system-wide software installation.

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: I have not personally tried this (systems that are able to boot from an SD card slot are rather rare in my experience), but I see no reason why it shouldn’t work. As long as your system’s firmware can access the SD card at boot time, you should be able to just install Kicksecure onto it like you’d install it persistently on a USB drive, and then use it. Linux sees SD cards as block device just like USB drives and internal drives, so there should be no issues there.

item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
This might be a tricky one. Apple keyboard backlights are apparently controlled by a sysfs file, which likely requires administrator permissions to modify. Existing tools might not work with user-sysmaint-split installed unless they install a privileged background process that actually does the job of changing the backlight brightness. If you remove user-sysmaint-split though, you might be able to use something like brightnessctl to adjust the keyboard backlight.

I unfortunately do not have an Intel-based Macbook to test with, so I can’t really create a tool for adjusting this that integrates with Kicksecure. (I made a tool for adjusting the display backlight, which is part of Kicksecure 18; a similar tool would probably work for the keyboard backlight, but would require someone with compatible hardware to create the tool or add support for keyboard backlight changing to the existing tool.)

item.title: Kicksecure IPv6 Default Settings (17.4.4.6 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
exfil:

Does disabling the IPv6 network stack on my machine then in return prevent the Tor Daemons from using IPv6 relays? (Reduced relay pool to select from)
Will Tor only connect to IPv4 relays and ignore IPv6 relays?

For guard relays, almost certainly yes. If your machine can’t connect to other machines over IPv6, Tor won’t be able to either. The guard relays however might then talk to other relays that do have IPv6 support.

exfil:

Can we enable full IPv6 (for Tor daemon’s IPv6 relay access and machine outbound) with privacy extensions, while maintaining a stable IPv6 address bound to your DHCPv6 server’s DUID for reliable client leasing and server reachability as to not add breakage for users needing the IPv6 server?

Not sure, research in this area would be welcome if a contributor is interested in working on it. My experience with IPv6 automatic address assignment is mostly with SLAAC, so I don’t have much insight into what can be done with DHCPv6.

item.title: Kicksecure Installer Settings (17.4.4.6 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
exfil:

Version: Kicksecure 17.4.4.6

FYI, Kicksecure 18 is out and 17 will likely be deprecated soon. If you have the time, you might want to give it a shot, it has a lot of neat security improvements over version 17 (like Wayland by default and a “panic button” for instant shutdown).

exfil:

Under timezone there is no Etc/UTC which I really wanted to set and had to set after post install timedatectl set-timezone "Etc/UTC". This isn’t really Kicksecures fault but a Calamares configuration issue. I believe this timezone is omitted or ignored in the default installer but I haven’t digged enough yet to see.

Using Etc/UTC as a timezone is more of an anonymity measure than a security one, and we generally keep the anonymity enhancements in Whonix. That being said, this does still sound like a useful feature, maybe you could file a request for this at https://codeberg.org/Calamares/calamares/issues?

exfil:

Is there a way to expose a “show password” option for the LUKS field in the Calamares configuration? If not, perhaps this could be proposed upstream to libkpmcore?

That would also be a good thing to file a feature request for. Doesn’t look like the feature exists at first glance.

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
Hi all,

Ok, so I’m a TAILS OS user from wayback, but, as you all know, its not the most convenient ‘daily driver’ option, hence, I like the idea of KS/Whonix on a persistent USB.

To that end, has anyone manged to clone this configuration to a MicroSD card?

I have my ‘persistent’ TAILS OS on a 32GB MicroSD, which makes portable concealment that much easier.

Cheers.

item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
Hi all,

I can’t for the life of me workout how to adjust the keyboard backlight on my Intel MacBook Pro.

The “Keyboard & Mouse” settings panel in KS is not an option because it is non-functional and the suggested workaround is beyond my pay grade at this early stage.

The actual keyboard ‘keys’ do nothing.

Tips and advice greatly appreciated.

Cheers.

item.title: Can't open proton VPN in kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description: Does Kicksecure set Polkit policies for default shipped apps or common apps for user stability?

item.title: KS persistent USB install issue, Linux Mint/Intel MacBook Pro
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
arraybolt3:

Edit: You “created two equal Live ISO images, each on a separate USB Drive, as per instructions”? I don’t think the instructions say to do that; you aren’t supposed to flash the Kicksecure ISO to the installation target drive. You’re only supposed to flash it to the installation source drive, then you boot from the source drive and install Kicksecure to the target drive like you’d install it to an internal drive. wipefs will probably fix the target drive in this scenario.

Yeah you install the ISO to USB like you would any Linux ISO, then at GRUB screen select SYSMAINT installation. Then once booted to the desktop where the SYSMAINT panel appears plug in another flash drive and start the Installer then the other USB drive will appear as a media selection to install Kicksecure onto. This is no different then installing on internal or external HDD/SSD, you just got to make sure you plug in the media you wish to install from so the installer can read it and make sure you select the right drive.

item.title: Kicksecure IPv6 Default Settings (17.4.4.6 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Installation Details

Version: Kicksecure 17.4.4.6

Install medium: Sandisk USB

Partition format: ext4 (auto-formatted)

I recall reading that the security‑misc profile disables the entire IPv6 stack. After installing, however, I verified that IPv6 is still active:
Upon post install I checked and cat /proc/sys/net/ipv6/conf/all/disable_ipv6 returned 0 (enabled) and ip -6 addr show returned a inet6 address.

I had to create a config file /etc/sysctl.d/99_disable-ipv6.conf with these lines to disable it:

net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6=1
net.ipv6.conf.default.disable_ipv6=1

Upon further looking at the github README:

Networking:

Optional - Disable the entire IPv6 stack to reduce attack surface.

But it doesn’t point to the exact configuration file that implements this.

I’m not using this installation as a server, and I’m skeptical of the “IPv6 evangelism” that circulates in many networking sysadmin circles, not Kicksecure. My concerns stem mainly from two points:

  • IPv6 doesn’t provide the implicit NAT barrier that IPv4 does.
  • Privacy implications of EUI‑64 that can expose hardware identifiers.

So here are two questions about IPv6 and Kicksecure.

1. Does Disabling IPv6 reduce Tor Anonymity set?

Does disabling the IPv6 network stack on my machine then in return prevent the Tor Daemons from using IPv6 relays? (Reduced relay pool to select from)
Will Tor only connect to IPv4 relays and ignore IPv6 relays?

2. Can we have IPv6 privacy extensions enabled without breaking root DHCP server?

Can we enable full IPv6 (for Tor daemon’s IPv6 relay access and machine outbound) with privacy extensions, while maintaining a stable IPv6 address bound to your DHCPv6 server’s DUID for reliable client leasing and server reachability as to not add breakage for users needing the IPv6 server?

Config note here worth mentioning man nm-settings-dbus

The special values “llt” and “ll” will generate a DUID of type LLT or LL (see RFC 3315) based on the current MAC address of the device.
dhcp-duid=ll # Fallbacks to link-local DUID for IPv6

The bottom line is can we keep a stable, DUID derived address for server accessibility while also generating temporary privacy focused addresses for outbound traffic (Tor relay/daemon and general machine use like e.g. in a users post about reticulum use)?

item.title: Kicksecure Removable Media plugin (17.4.4.6 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Installation Details

Version: Kicksecure 17.4.4.6

Install medium: Sandisk USB

Partition format: ext4 (auto-formatted)

This post is about what I believe to be called the Volume Manager plugin.

  • System volumes shown

After install I noticed the “Removable Media” plugin on the lxqt panel in the upper right corner shows /boot, /rootfs, and /efi as mount points. Can the widget be told to ignore system or not show system volumes? I can see users accidentally unmounting these.

  • “Removable Media” showing on center of desktop at boot

After I booted I saw the panel plugin the center of screen as if it was a desktop icon but after like 5 seconds it disappeared. My guess is it is a bug with Wayland? Thought I would mention it.

item.title: Virtualbox error Kernel driver not installed (rc=-1908)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
I think the step that’s missing is that the instructions aren’t telling you to reinstall packages that ship DKMS modules. You might want to try sudo apt reinstall virtualbox-7.2 before giving up. That might get things working.

If you just want to uninstall VirtualBox, sudo apt purge virtualbox-7.2 should work.

item.title: Kicksecure Installer Settings (17.4.4.6 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
I’d like to break my feedback into separate posts, each covering a single topic, to keep things clear. First, I have to say I’m genuinely impressed with Kicksecure. Over the years I’ve written countless post install scripts just to harden a vanilla Debian installation. Despite trying several distributions, I always end up back at Debian. Only to be frustrated by its insecure defaults and the tedious manual hardening required. Literally editing config files till I go crazy lol. Kicksecure feels refreshingly different, the defaults are already security focused, which is fantastic. Kudos to the developers and the community!

Installation Details

Version: Kicksecure 17.4.4.6

Install medium: Sandisk USB

Partition format: ext4 (auto-formatted)

I flashed the ISO to one USB stick, then used a second USB as the target for the installation (for testing purposes).

  • Missing “Etc/UTC” Timezone Option

Under timezone there is no Etc/UTC which I really wanted to set and had to set after post install timedatectl set-timezone "Etc/UTC". This isn’t really Kicksecures fault but a Calamares configuration issue. I believe this timezone is omitted or ignored in the default installer but I haven’t digged enough yet to see.

  • Can’t show LUKS password (LUKS Password Visibility)

Again, this is an installer side matter rather than a Kicksecure problem. While many installers (e.g., Ubuntu) let you toggle password visibility for user accounts, the Calamares stage that collects the LUKS passphrase lacks such a toggle. In a previous Debian install, long some time ago I entered the wrong LUKS password. I had to reinstall cause I was off on the keys I set for the LUKS password at this stage.

Is there a way to expose a “show password” option for the LUKS field in the Calamares configuration? If not, perhaps this could be proposed upstream to libkpmcore?

item.title: Virtualbox error Kernel driver not installed (rc=-1908)
item.dc:creator: @ValdemarJo
item.description: I got a blue screen. I followed the instructions ( Secure Boot ) up to step 12. I did the same thing on older versions of Kicksecure and it worked. The key is added correctly, but VirtualBox doesn’t work. I installed it using virtualbox-installer-cli. I want to reinstall VirtualBox, but I can’t uninstall it; the standard commands don’t work. What’s the command to uninstall VirtualBox?

item.title: Virtualbox error Kernel driver not installed (rc=-1908)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: Did you see the “Shim UEFI key management” blue screen after rebooting? If not, that’s why things aren’t working and we should debug that.

item.title: Virtualbox error Kernel driver not installed (rc=-1908)
item.dc:creator: @ValdemarJo
item.description:
Please explain in detail how to make it work; I have little experience.

I followed these instructions up to step 12 and registered the key, but VirtualBox isn’t working.
Issuer: CN=DKMS module signing key
Subject: CN=DKMS module signing key

I had no problems with previous versions of kicksecure. I also registered the key, and VirtualBox worked with secureboot enabled.

Install mokutil package(s) following these instructions.

  1. Platform specific notice.

Kicksecure: No special notice.
Kicksecure-Qubes: In Template.

  1. Update the package lists and upgrade the system.

sudo apt update && sudo apt full-upgrade

  1. Install the mokutil package(s).

Using the apt command line, the --no-install-recommends option is optional in most cases.

sudo apt install --no-install-recommends mokutil

4 Platform specific notice.

Kicksecure: No special notice.
Kicksecure-Qubes: Shut down Template and restart App Qubes based on it as per Qubes Template Modification.

5 Done.

The procedure of installing package(s) mokutil is complete.

  1. Check if Secure Boot is enabled:

sudo mokutil --sb-state

Expected output:

SecureBoot enabled

If Secure Boot is disabled:
If you wish to enable it, see Enable Secure Boot.
If you do not wish to enable it, no further steps from this wiki chapter need to be applied.
If Secure Boot is enabled:
Proceed with the steps below.

  1. Import the DKMS MOK key.

sudo mokutil --import /var/lib/dkms/mok.pub

  1. Password entry.

You’ll be prompted to create a password. Enter it twice.

  1. Reboot the computer.

sudo reboot

item.title: Install virtualbox error
item.dc:creator: @ValdemarJo

item.title: Virtualbox error Kernel driver not installed (rc=-1908)
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
See:

Kicksecure – 19 Dec 25

Secure Boot

Information on Secure Boot and DKMS Signing Key (MOK Key) Enrollment to ensure kernel modules can be loaded on systems with Secure Boot enabled.

item.title: Virtualbox error Kernel driver not installed (rc=-1908)
item.dc:creator: @ValdemarJo
item.description:
Hello, virtualbox does not work when secureboot is enabled.

Kernel driver not installed (rc=-1908)

The VirtualBox Linux kernel driver is either not loaded or not set up correctly. Please try setting it up again by executing

‘/sbin/vboxconfig’

as root.

If your system has EFI Secure Boot enabled you may also need to sign the kernel modules (vboxdrv, vboxnetflt, vboxnetadp, vboxpci) before you can load them. Please see your Linux system’s documentation for more information.

where: suplibOsInit what: 3 VERR_VM_DRIVER_NOT_INSTALLED (-1908) - The support driver is not installed. On linux, open returned ENOENT.

How to fix it? I don’t want to disable secureboot.

Ok, so all good thanks.

Whonix successfully installed. The Installer in Kicksecure worked brilliantly, probably the easiest group install I’ve done. Well done dev. folk.

Cheers.

item.dc:creator: @Avoca

That worked, thank you.

All good, now I’ll move on to installing Whonix on the KS USB via ‘the guide’.

Cheers.

item.title: KS persistent USB install issue, Linux Mint/Intel MacBook Pro
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
Awesome, thanks.

The only reason I ended-up with two identical USB drives was because nothing else worked either.

I had tried, via GNOME Disks, all USB Format options previously without success and figured, why not try this as well, so I used “Create bootable disk…” option in the Mint File Manager.

Anyway, I’ll give your cli code a whirl and have another go.

Cheers.

item.title: KS persistent USB install issue, Linux Mint/Intel MacBook Pro
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
Try booting from the live Kicksecure USB, then run sudo wipefs --all /dev/USB_DEVICE, replacing USB_DEVICE with the device you intend to install Kicksecure to. Be warned, this will delete all data on the target device (recovery might be possible but is definitely non-trivial), so be very careful to specify the right device and make sure the target USB doesn’t have any data you care about. (lsblk is usually helpful if you need to figure out which device is the right device.)

Once that’s done, reboot and try to install onto the target USB again. Hopefully that should fix whatever is making Calamares ignore the target USB.

Edit: You “created two equal Live ISO images, each on a separate USB Drive, as per instructions”? I don’t think the instructions say to do that; you aren’t supposed to flash the Kicksecure ISO to the installation target drive. You’re only supposed to flash it to the installation source drive, then you boot from the source drive and install Kicksecure to the target drive like you’d install it to an internal drive. wipefs will probably fix the target drive in this scenario.

item.title: KS persistent USB install issue, Linux Mint/Intel MacBook Pro
item.dc:creator: @Avoca

Trying to create a Persistent Whonix USB stick. I have created two equal Live ISO images, each on a separate USB Drive, as per instructions.

However, the second USB Drive does not show as an installation option in the KS Install app in the maintenance section. Only my system SSD and an External Backup Drive I use.

Any pointers/tips greatly appreciated.

Cheers.

item.title: Running Android Apps inside Kicksecure - Waydroid
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description:
suse211213:

waydroid works on Kicksecure 18

Check Waydroid tickets, its a buggy dead project unrelated to kicksecure or wayland/debian.

item.title: Morphing K18 on Trixie issues
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
We might be having an XY Problem here.

This message can be safely ignored:

GaS58Bc:

Info: File /var/swapfile on LUKS encrypted device: ‘no’. - Doing nothing, ok.

It starts with INFO: and ends with ok. So unless that is something you’re interested in, you can very safely move your focus away from these kind of messages.

Once that message is shown, all that swap-file-creator does is exit 0, which means it terminates itself with status “success”. And that’s it. swap-file-creator won’t have any future effect on the boot or system.

GaS58Bc:

but usb with ks18 morphed on trixie

If you want to morph, then morph. Note that this is a method for advanced users. Unless you have a strong rationale why distribution morphing is useful, there is no need to do distribution morphing.

Kicksecure on USB can be done according to:

Kicksecure – 18 Dec 25

Installation of Kicksecure on a USB

Yes, Kicksecure can be installed on a USB. Here's how.

No distribution morphing required.

GaS58Bc:

If you were to install to a usb, what setting would you choose to avoid swapfile creator issues?

There are no issues.

GaS58Bc:

The pc has a lot of ram.

In this case, never mind swap-file-creator. It’s not needed and can be ignored.

If the boot is frozen after swap-file-creator, doesn’t mean it’s caused by swap-file-creator.

Now that I think about it, having a swapfile versus not having one isn’t important enough to be shown during boot. If there is enough RAM (at the time of writing 2 GB), then swap-file-creator does not need to say anything at all by default. So that’s a usability bug which will be fixed in the next release.

In the future, we can move information level messages can be moved to systemcheck.

I used to be under the impression, swap-file-creator is the thing you’re interested here. However, it might be a different issue. Frozen boot? In that case, we can suggest other things. In that case…

As per Recovery Mode…

  • Remove kernel parameter loglevel=0 and quiet.
  • Follow the Temporary Kernel Boot Parameter Change instructions to change the kernel parameters.

item.title: Install virtualbox error
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Which installation instructions did you use? Unfortunately, installation of VirtualBox is difficult. [1]

As Kicksecure user, you can use virtualbox-installer-cli, which is installed by default:

virtualbox-installer-cli

See also:

Kicksecure – 3 Jan 26

Kicksecure Linux Installer for VirtualBox

Kicksecure for Linux - Stable Version

Kicksecure – 3 Jan 26

VirtualBox Installer for Linux

The VirtualBox Linux Installer offers a user-friendly method to install VirtualBox on Linux systems. It supports Debian, Fedora, and their derivatives such as Ubuntu (starting from version: Ubuntu Jammy (22.04) (LTS)), Linux Mint, RedHat, and...

Alternatively, this could be done manually using instructions install VirtualBox from the virtualbox.org repository.

[1] VirtualBox Unavailable in Debian stable and backports due to Debian Stable Security Maintenance Issues

item.title: Morphing K18 on Trixie issues
item.dc:creator: @GaS58Bc
item.description:
Thank you Patrick. I’m gonna have a strong flask of coffee and read all this, but in parallel, if my endgame is not a VBox VM but usb with ks18 morphed on trixie, should I:

  • install d13 from inside the live d13 lxqt iso, select encryption and default partition etc
  • Run k18 commands
  • Disable swapfile to get past it or do something else? Sorry dumb question

So far my attempts with usb or VM using with d13 net iso or ixqt have not got me past swapfile creator during boot. I’m too dumb to know if this is down to d13 configuration or my k18 choices. If you were to install to a usb, what setting would you choose to avoid swapfile creator issues? The pc has a lot of ram. Very appreciative of your patience and support

item.title: VeraCrypt: unable to decrypt or mount any volume; it says that the device is busy
item.dc:creator: @Roxy
item.description: it worked after commenting the line, thanks.

item.title: Running Android Apps inside Kicksecure - Waydroid
item.dc:creator: @suse211213
item.description:
Emulators like genymotion (sadly not open source) should offers better isolation from the host system than Waydroid . Better performance and malware protection .

Waydroid shares the host Linux kernel, which presents a higher potential security risk if the container is compromised.

Unfortunately, no open source emulator exists yet.

I would vote for Android on VM to protect host system from malicious apks even no solution is entirely foolproof

item.title: 3 big issues in Kicksecure 18 (my laptop is basically unusable now)
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Related:

Kicksecure – 17 Dec 25

Other Desktop Environments

How to use Other Desktop Environments other than LXQt with Kicksecure. Current situation. Risks. Future. (Gnome, KDE, Xfce, MATE, ...)

item.title: Morphing K18 on Trixie issues
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Yes. As expected. It’s mentioned in the documentation but not obvious to find. See also:

Kicksecure – 30 Nov 25

swap-file-creator

Creates a swap file on LUKS-encrypted systems, optionally on unencrypted disks.

I wonder if the info message can be improved.

github.com/Kicksecure/swap-file-creator

usr/share/swap-file-creator/swap-file-creator

master 

      
    
          
  1.    systemd_detect_virt_output=""
    2. 
          
  2. fi
    3. 
          
  3. 
          
  4. if [ "$DO_PRE_CHECK" = 'yes' ]; then
    5. 
          
  5.    if [ "$systemd_detect_virt_output" = "xen" ]; then
    6. 
          
  6.       printf '%s\n' "INFO: Virtualizer 'xen' detected. Could be 'Qubes'. Skipping swap-file-creator. Doing nothing, ok."
    7. 
          
  7.       exit 0
    8. 
          
  8.    fi
    9. 
          
  9. 
          
  10.    if ! luks-path-check "$SWAPFILE" &>/dev/null ; then
    11. 
          
  11.       printf '%s\n' "INFO: File '$SWAPFILE' on LUKS encrypted device: 'no'. - Doing nothing, ok."
    12. 
          
  12.       exit 0
    13. 
          
  13.    else
    14. 
          
  14.       pre_check_done='true'
    15. 
          
  15.    fi
    16. 
          
  16. fi
    17. 
          
  17. 
          
  18. ## User can set HIBERNATION=yes in /etc/default/swap-file-creator
    19. 
          
  19. [[ -v "HIBERNATION" ]] || HIBERNATION="$hibernation_consideration"
    20. 
          
  20. 
          
  21. total_ram_in_mb="$(free -m | sed  -n -e '/^Mem:/s/^[^0-9]*\([0-9]*\) .*/\1/p')"
    22.

Perhaps we could add a short link there?

See also: https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/swap

item.title: Running Android Apps inside Kicksecure - Waydroid
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
I should have added:

Untested.

item.title: VeraCrypt: unable to decrypt or mount any volume; it says that the device is busy
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
arraybolt3:

Try editing /etc/default/grub.d/40_kernel_hardening.cfg, and comment out the line GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX="$GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX bdev_allow_write_mounted=0".

Plus run:

sudo update-grub

For more detailed instructions, see also:

Kicksecure – 15 Dec 25

grub bootloader Configuration Changes

Kernel Boot Parameter Changes

Alternatively, you could perhaps more easily use Temporary Kernel Boot Parameter Change to test this without the bdev_allow_write_mounted=0 kernel parameter.

item.title: Morphing K18 on Trixie issues
item.dc:creator: @GaS58Bc
item.description:
Little update. Created a new VM through the Debian 13 lxqt live installation process. Ticked the encryption box and accepted default partition etc. ks18 commands worked fine. FYI I’m using the install ‘for host os’ and not ‘for any other VMs (not qubes)’ - could be a wrong choice screw up on my part.

on reboot I have to enter encryption passphrase for grub, then KS splash, then again the passphrase for vbox_harddisk. Swapfile seems to work this time, e.g. enough ram; capping at 10% disk size; calculating swap file in mb 1998; then stops after ‘Info: File var/swapfile’ (1 GB) ready Ok.

Btw - thanks for all the advice so far….really appreciated

item.title: VeraCrypt: unable to decrypt or mount any volume; it says that the device is busy
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
Roxy:

After removing the SysMaint secure feature, I installed VeraCrypt, but I’m unable to decrypt or mount any volume; it says that the device is busy.

It’s hard to say what the root cause is without knowing the exact error message, but this might be a consequence of:

GitHub

Set `bdev_allow_write_mounted=0` · Kicksecure/security-misc@e43d4d7

Kernel Hardening; Protect Linux User Accounts against Brute Force Attacks; Improve Entropy Collection; Strong Linux User Account Separation; Enhances Misc Security Settings - https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Security-misc - Set...

Try editing /etc/default/grub.d/40_kernel_hardening.cfg, and comment out the line GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX="$GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX bdev_allow_write_mounted=0". Does that fix it?

Roxy:

The Tor Browser is crashing frequently.

Are any error messages shown when this happens? If you run torbrowser in a terminal, then use it until it crashes, are any messages printed to the terminal immediately before the crash?

item.title: Morphing K18 on Trixie issues
item.dc:creator: @GaS58Bc
item.description: Ah, didnt enable encryption - let me try again. Thanks again buddy

item.title: Morphing K18 on Trixie issues
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
GaS58Bc:

D13 lqxt iso, using normal installer, skipped root user setup, partition = guided entire disk (no lvm, no encryption), all files in one partition - reboot ok - all KS commands executed ok - reboot - same result as before - after ks splash - swap-file-creator message ‘File ‘/var/swapfile’ on LUKS encrypted device: no - do nothing ok.

Yes, that is expected behavior. swap-file-creator only creates swapfiles on encrypted volumes for security reasons, and only creates them directly on LUKS volumes.

GaS58Bc:

D13 lqxt iso live boot, installed from within live using defaults for partition, no root user etc - reboot ok - all ks commands executed ok - reboot same result as above

Did you enable encryption here? The live installer has a checkbox on the partitioning screen for “Encrypt disk”, right above the partition layout summary. (This will give you LUKS without LVM, which is what you want.)

item.title: VeraCrypt: unable to decrypt or mount any volume; it says that the device is busy
item.dc:creator: @Roxy
item.description:
Big Issues After Installing Kicksecure 18

  1. After removing the SysMaint secure feature, I installed VeraCrypt, but I’m unable to decrypt or mount any volume; it says that the device is busy.
  2. The Tor Browser is crashing frequently.

any suggestions?
